description: From earlier craunch, cranch, of imitative origin.

entries.meaning: A noisy crackling sound; the sound usually associated with crunching.

examples: The friends, on the contrary, argue that Job does not "know", that only God knows; yet, when it comes to the crunch, they themselves seem to know as much as God knows: for example, that Job is a guilty sinner.

entries.meaning: A problem that leads to a crisis.
(exercise) A form of abdominal exercise, based on a sit-up but in which the lower back remains in contact with the floor.
(software engineering, slang) The overtime work required to catch up and finish a project, usually in the final weeks of development before release.
A dessert consisting of a crunchy topping with fruit underneath.
(cooking, generally in the plural) A small piece created by crushing; a piece of material with a friable or crunchy texture.

verbs.description: crunch (third-person singular simple present crunches, present participle crunching, simple past and past participle crunched)

entries.meaning: To crush something, especially food, with a noisy crackling sound.
examples: When I came home, Susan was watching TV with her feet up on the couch, crunching a piece of celery.

entries.meaning: To be crushed with a noisy crackling sound.
examples: Beetles crunched beneath the men's heavy boots as they worked.

entries.meaning: (slang) To calculate or otherwise process (e.g. to crunch numbers: to perform mathematical calculations). Presumably from the sound made by mechanical calculators.
examples: That metadata makes it much easier for the search engine to crunch the data for queries.

entries.meaning: To grind or press with violence and noise.
To emit a grinding or crunching noise.
examples: There were sounds in the air above his head – sounds of the crunching and rattling of the loose, smooth stones as his neighbors moved about […]

entries.meaning: (automotive, transitive) To cause the gears to emit a crunching sound by releasing the clutch before the gears are properly synchronised.
(computing, transitive) To compress (data) using a particular algorithm, so that it can be restored by decrunching.
examples: PackIt will not crunch executables, unless told to do so.

entries.meaning: (software engineering, slang, transitive) To make employees work overtime in order to meet a deadline in the development of a project.
